Among the most 
      restrained and discreet people on the planet, spies, especially the top 
      spy, usually remain silent. But former CIA Director George Tenet lets 
      loose in our first story in a public venting rare for any public official, 
      never mind a CIA director. Tenet angrily accuses the Bush 
      administration of ruining his reputation by misusing his now-famous "slam 
      dunk" remark about Iraqi WMD to justify its march to war. "It’s the most 
      despicable thing that ever happened to me," Tenet says. "You don’t do 
      this. You don’t throw somebody overboard just because it’s a deflection. 
      Is that honorable? It’s not honorable to me," he tells correspondent Scott Pelley. 
       He also reveals in this double-length segment his anguish and 
      frustration over the 9/11 attack, the first of the president’s inner 
      circle to provide a glimpse inside it during what many would consider the 
      country’s darkest hour in modern times. You’ll hear and see his feelings 
      on the hunt for Osama bin Laden, the war on terror and its "enhanced 
      interrogation" methods he says were not torture and saved 
      lives. Pressed by Pelley to explain why, if it wasn’t torture,  
      these individuals had to have their interrogations "enhanced," Tenet, 
      leans forward to respond, "Because these are people who will never, ever, 
      ever tell you a thing. These are people who know who’s responsible for the 
      next terrorist attack….[who] wouldn’t blink an eyelash about killing you, 
      your family, me and my family and everybody in this town." 
         
 
Watch An Excerpt Of Pelley's 
      Report.
 
With the questions still 
      hovering over the massacre at Virginia Tech last week, correspondent Steve Kroft 
      explores perhaps the biggest irony in the horrible event. It’s the fact 
      that Seung-Hui Cho, with a history of mental illness, was still able to 
      purchase the guns he used to kill 32 innocent people, despite a 
      40-year-old federal law prohibiting the sale of guns to the mentally 
      ill. Kroft reports that the law isn’t enforced because many states 
      have laws that protect the privacy of the mentally ill, advocates for whom 
      still want their records sealed and not shared with other government 
      agencies. Even the NRA won’t go that far. The sad fact is that Cho 
      wasn’t the first mentally ill person to kill with a gun he purchased 
      freely, nor will he be likely the last.
